title: Top vet says trendy 'extra protein' pet foods don't provide better nutrition
text:

High protein foods have been one of the biggest food crazes in recent years for humans and animals.

Proteins are the building blocks of the body for both animals and humans, essential for energy, growth and tissue repair.

But pet owners could be wasting their money AND harming the environment by paying out for such 'lean high protein' products our furry friends don't necessarily need.

PURINA has been one of the leaders in the advancement of pet care and pet nutrition for over 125 years and its nutritionists have today issued a warning to pet owners to say: "More protein does not necessarily mean better nutrition!"

PURINA's Technical Communication Manager and Veterinarian nutritionist, Jenifer Molina, explained: "Feeding extra protein, in excess of the amount that your pet requires, provides no health benefit to your pet and can potentially harm the environment.

"Although, the protein level is one of the key points to take into account when choosing your pet's food, the objective is to ensure that the food contains the required amount of protein for the specific needs of the pet (taking into account life stage and/or illnesses the animal could suffer from).

"When proteins are consumed in excess, the body will not have the capacity to store them and, therefore, the excessive protein will not be used to create more muscle mass. Consequently, the excess of protein will probably end up in urine or faeces, which is not harmful for pets, as long as they are healthy.

"However, feeding pets an excessive quantity of proteins may become an environmental issue, given the amount of excreted nitrogen that comes from the protein metabolism."

PURINA uses animal based raw materials or animal by-products (such as chicken, beef, lamb) in its balanced pet foods.

Jenifer continued: "Animal by-products are sometimes thought to be low quality ingredients that shouldn’t be included in pet foods - but this simply isn't the case.

"To be permitted in pet food they must come from animals deemed for human consumption and slaughtered under veterinary supervision. Once not intended for human consumption it becomes an animal by-product.

"The pet food industry uses surplus products from the human food chain and Purina purchases all by-products from approved suppliers."

“Animal by-products are a good source of protein, essential fatty acids, iron and some B group vitamins; so not only are they great for your pet, they are also enjoyed by them.”
description: PURINA expert explains why feeding an excess amount of protein to a pet provides them no health benefit
